H0.text: Predicting solar eclipses is the task for which the Hubble Space Telescope, launched by NASA into space in 1990, provides better accuracy than a land‑based telescope, making it the preferred choice for scientists.

H1.text: Investigating faraway galaxies is where the Hubble Space Telescope, launched into space by NASA in 1990, provides better accuracy than a land‑based telescope, which is why scientists most likely prefer it.

H2.text: Investigating the size of Venus is the activity for which scientists prefer the Hubble Space Telescope, launched into space by NASA in 1990, because it provides better accuracy than a land‑based telescope.

H3.text: Predicting the phases of the Moon is the reason scientists most likely prefer to use the Hubble Space Telescope, launched by NASA into space in 1990, over a land‑based telescope because it provides better accuracy.

A4.text: Hubble can image more faint objects, since ground‑based telescopes are affected by the background of scattered light created by the Earth's atmosphere.

A5.text: Large ground‑based telescopes can image some of the same wavelengths as Hubble, sometimes challenge HST in terms of resolution by using adaptive optics (AO).

A6.text: The HUDF contains about 10,000 galaxies, the oldest of which are seen as they were 13.2 billion years ago.

A7.text: The HUDF image was taken in a section of the sky with a low density of bright stars in the near-field, allowing much better viewing of dimmer, more distant objects.
